授業目的: Are you interested in becoming an entrepreneur or an innovative manager (an intrapreneur)? Are you curious about how dynamic technological innovation has shaped competitive conditions in markets and industries? Are you interested in exploring how dynamic technological innovation, societal, cultural, economic and political forces interact to generate the world we live in and where human kind is going in the future? This course will examine from the perspective of practicing managers and entrepreneurs the impact that technology and technological innovation has on the competitive context of organizations and how strategy must incorporate this impact. This course will also provide an opportunity to explore the relationships between the management of a business and the management of technological innovation; of the scientific quest for knowledge and the technological use of knowledge; and of the firm as an instrument of technological change in the broader context of society. Further we examine the role of entrepreneurs and intrapreneurs as leaders and entrepreneurship in fostering technological innovation and contrast and compare that role with established incumbent firms. We will accomplish these tasks through the use of hands on decision making through computer simulations of innovative environments, living cases presented by currently practicing manages (based on schedule availability) and traditional cases where you will experience the challenges of creating the future through entrepreneurship and technological innovation.
到達目標: Upon completion of this course, the student will be able to demonstrate the following learning outcomes: 1) Identify key elements of entrepreneurship, technology and innovation. 2) Analyze the relationship between entrepreneurs and incumbent firms in fostering technological innovation. 3) Understand the role of entrepreneurs and mangers in incumbent firms in generating technological innovation and in particular students should be able to self-reflect on their own abilities to be effective entrepreneurs. 4) Be able to think critically and laterally and express coherently that thinking both verbally and in written form. 5.) Have experienced hands on decision-making in environments characterized by uncertainty and dynamic innovation.
授業方法: The course will be taught with a combination of computer simulation, living cases (based on schedule availability), lectures, and traditional case analyses and student presentations and other in-class simulations. Lecture and discussion of cases (both written and video) based on conceptual frameworks found in current research and articles appearing in leading academic journals and business publications. Application of these conceptual frameworks and present your analysis of the cases in both written and oral formats will be accomplished through a variety of approaches including discussion, team and individual presentations, quizzes, in-class exercises among others. Throughout the term we will form a learning community in understanding leadership in management.
